title: Ukrainian Officials Attend 'Blue Economy' Training in Xiamen in 2019
description: From September 8, 2019 to October 1, 2019, the Fujian Institute of Oceanography in Xiamen (People's Republic of China) hosted a seminar on the promotion of the "blue economy" (Seminar on Promotion of Blue Economic Development via ICM for Ukraine). Representatives of the State Fisheries Agency, the State Water Agency, the Ministry of Energy, the Ministry of Economic Agriculture, the Ministry of Infrastructure, the Government Office of the Cabinet of Ministers and specialists of domestic research institutions took part in the training program. Those visiting learned about coastal management, the preservation and formation of river deltas, and dams. They were taught by Chinese researchers on these topics from not only the Fujian Institute of Oceanography but also the Qingdao Institute of Marine Geology.
combined_text:
# Sector
GENERAL ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION

# Title
Ukrainian Officials Attend 'Blue Economy' Training in Xiamen in 2019

# Description
From September 8, 2019 to October 1, 2019, the Fujian Institute of Oceanography in Xiamen (People's Republic of China) hosted a seminar on the promotion of the "blue economy" (Seminar on Promotion of Blue Economic Development via ICM for Ukraine). Representatives of the State Fisheries Agency, the State Water Agency, the Ministry of Energy, the Ministry of Economic Agriculture, the Ministry of Infrastructure, the Government Office of the Cabinet of Ministers and specialists of domestic research institutions took part in the training program. Those visiting learned about coastal management, the preservation and formation of river deltas, and dams. They were taught by Chinese researchers on these topics from not only the Fujian Institute of Oceanography but also the Qingdao Institute of Marine Geology.
justification: Training program focused on knowledge sharing and capacity building in environmental protection and coastal management
evidence: Seminar on blue economy, focus on coastal management and river delta preservation, participation of government officials and researchers

title: PowerChina Guizhou Engineering provides a EUR 80.6 million supplier's credit for 148 MW Progressovka Solar Power Plant Project
description: In 2019, financial closure was reached on the 148 MW Progressovka Solar Power Plant Project, located in the Mykolayiv region of Ukraine. Chinese state-owned PowerChina Guizhou Engineering Co., Ltd. provided a two-year construction financing supplier's credit facility (loan) worth approximately EUR 80.6 million to Scatec Solar for the 148 MW Progressovka solar power plant in the Mykolayiv region of Ukraine. This facility carried a maturity period of two years and a final maturity date in June 2022. Scatec ASA provided a corporate guarantee for this facility. The facility was classified as trade and other payables in Scatec's financial statements. The proceeds of this facility were intended to be used by the borrower to finance an engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract with PowerChina Guizhou Engineering Co., Ltd. As of June 2019, Scatec Solar was in advanced stages of securing long-term debt financing as well as an equity partner for the project.  Scatec Solar, a Norwegian company, was the equity investor and will also provide engineering procurement and construction management, operation and maintenance as well as asset management services.  PowerChina Guizhou Engineering Co., Ltd.  was the EPC contractor. This project was also supported by Ukraine's feed-in tariff or green tariff, which provides state support to renewable power producers. Progressovka Solar PV Park was a ground-mounted solar project which is spread over an area of 200 hectares. The 148 MW solar plant was expected to deliver 187 GWh per year. Risen Energy supplied the Photo Voltaic modules for the project. Huawei Technologies supplied its SUN2000-185 KTL inverters to the project site. Construction began on June 3, 2019 and was initially expected to be in commercial operation by the first half of 2020 (June 30, 2020 by the latest). It began commercial operations on July 1, 2021.
staff_comments: 1. The two-year construction financing facility covered 65% of the value of the EUR 124 million capital expenditure for the project. Therefore, AidData has coded the transaction amount of this project as EUR 80.6 million, which is 65% of EUR 124 million.2. The exact commitment date of this loan is unknown. It was initially mentioned in June 2019 as part of the financing for this project; however, its two-year maturity period and June 2022 maturity date suggests a commitment or drawn down in the loan proceeds in 2020. For now, AidData has assumed the loan was commited in 2019, as that was when it was first mentioned in that year and the project reached financial closure that year, but has marked the commitment_date_estimated? field as True. This issue merits further investigation.
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
PowerChina Guizhou Engineering provides a EUR 80.6 million supplier's credit for 148 MW Progressovka Solar Power Plant Project

# Description
In 2019, financial closure was reached on the 148 MW Progressovka Solar Power Plant Project, located in the Mykolayiv region of Ukraine. Chinese state-owned PowerChina Guizhou Engineering Co., Ltd. provided a two-year construction financing supplier's credit facility (loan) worth approximately EUR 80.6 million to Scatec Solar for the 148 MW Progressovka solar power plant in the Mykolayiv region of Ukraine. This facility carried a maturity period of two years and a final maturity date in June 2022. Scatec ASA provided a corporate guarantee for this facility. The facility was classified as trade and other payables in Scatec's financial statements. The proceeds of this facility were intended to be used by the borrower to finance an engineering, procurement, and construction (EPC) contract with PowerChina Guizhou Engineering Co., Ltd. As of June 2019, Scatec Solar was in advanced stages of securing long-term debt financing as well as an equity partner for the project.  Scatec Solar, a Norwegian company, was the equity investor and will also provide engineering procurement and construction management, operation and maintenance as well as asset management services.  PowerChina Guizhou Engineering Co., Ltd.  was the EPC contractor. This project was also supported by Ukraine's feed-in tariff or green tariff, which provides state support to renewable power producers. Progressovka Solar PV Park was a ground-mounted solar project which is spread over an area of 200 hectares. The 148 MW solar plant was expected to deliver 187 GWh per year. Risen Energy supplied the Photo Voltaic modules for the project. Huawei Technologies supplied its SUN2000-185 KTL inverters to the project site. Construction began on June 3, 2019 and was initially expected to be in commercial operation by the first half of 2020 (June 30, 2020 by the latest). It began commercial operations on July 1, 2021.
justification: Primary purpose is solar power generation with clear renewable energy focus
evidence: 148 MW solar power plant, ground-mounted solar project, expected to deliver 187 GWh per year, supported by Ukraine's feed-in tariff for renewable power

title: China and Ukraine agree to conduct 32 joint scientific research projects in 2019-2020
description: From July to September 2018, the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine and the Ministry of Science and Technology of the People's Republic of China accepted applications from universities, research institutions and enterprises for joint Ukrainian-Chinese research projects for 2019-2020. Then in April 2019, China and Ukraine signed the "Program of Scientific and Technical Cooperation" for 2019-2020, which approved 32 joint scientific research projects. Ukraine's Ministry of Education and Science specifically funded 10 projects with UAH 140,000 each, for a total of UAH 1,400,000. The Chinese contribution to the projects is unclear.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China and Ukraine agree to conduct 32 joint scientific research projects in 2019-2020

# Description
From July to September 2018, the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine and the Ministry of Science and Technology of the People's Republic of China accepted applications from universities, research institutions and enterprises for joint Ukrainian-Chinese research projects for 2019-2020. Then in April 2019, China and Ukraine signed the "Program of Scientific and Technical Cooperation" for 2019-2020, which approved 32 joint scientific research projects. Ukraine's Ministry of Education and Science specifically funded 10 projects with UAH 140,000 each, for a total of UAH 1,400,000. The Chinese contribution to the projects is unclear.
justification: Project focuses on scientific research collaboration in education sector without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Joint scientific research projects between universities and research institutions, funded by education ministries

title: 45 Ukrainian citizens receive scholarships from China
description: In November 2019, the Chinese Ministry of Education made 45 scholarships available to Ukrainian citizens. Those selected will go to higher education institutions in China for bachelor, master, postgraduate, and internship programs.  These scholarships are likely a result of the Subcommission on cooperation in the field of education established in 2011.

title: Chinese Embassy donates cultural goods to Martial Arts School in Uruguay
description: On February 25, 2019, the Chinese Embassy donated cultural goods to a martial arts school in Uruguay. The cultural goods included props for the lion dance and outfits for Kongfu practices. The project aimed at promoting Chinese culture in Uruguay.

title: Chinese Embassy in Uruguay donates cultural supplies to a Wu Kendo Hall in Montevideo
description: According to a report from the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, on February 15, 2019, the Chinese Embassy in Uruguay donated cultural supplies to the a Wu Kendo Hall in Montevideo, Uruguay. This Kendo association (established in 2004) provides courses in in martial arts, Tai Chi, Qigong and traditional Chinese medicine all year round to 80 students. The gifts included Tai Chi fans, training clothes, knives and swords. The donation aimed to promote Chinese culture in Uruguay, as the museum has committed to do for 15 years.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

According to a report from the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, on February 15, 2019, the Chinese Embassy in Uruguay donated cultural supplies to the a Wu Kendo Hall in Montevideo, Uruguay. This Kendo association (established in 2004) provides courses in in martial arts, Tai Chi, Qigong and traditional Chinese medicine all year round to 80 students. The gifts included Tai Chi fans, training clothes, knives and swords. The donation aimed to promote Chinese culture in Uruguay, as the museum has committed to do for 15 years.
